meanings.def: used in negative sentences and questions to talk about something that has not happened but that you expect to happen
examples: (British English) I haven't received a letter from him yet.
(North American English) I didn't receive a letter from him yet.
not yet ‘Are you ready?’ ‘No, not yet.’
We don't yet know what really happened.
have yet to do something We have yet to decide what action to take (= We have not decided what action to take).
I already did it.
Did you eat yet?
I’ve already done it.
Have you eaten yet?
I already knew this because Mike had told me.
(British English) I’ve just had some bad news.
(North American English) I just got some bad news.
Don't go yet.
We don't need to start yet.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an increase in number or amount or the number of times something happens
examples: yet more… snow, snow and yet more snow
yet another… yet another diet book
yet again Prices were cut yet again (= once more, after many other times).

meanings.def: used to emphasize that something is the best, longest, etc. thing of its kind made, produced, written, etc. until now/then
examples: the most comprehensive study yet of his music
It was the tallest building yet constructed anywhere.

meanings.def: from now until the period of time mentioned has passed
examples: He'll be busy for ages yet.
They won't arrive for at least two hours yet.

meanings.def: used to say that something could, might, etc. happen in the future, even though it seems unlikely
examples: We may win yet.
(formal) She could yet surprise us all.

meanings.def: used to emphasize an increase in the degree of something (= how bad, important, etc. it is)
examples: a recent and yet more improbable theory

meanings.def: until now or until a particular time in the past
examples: an as yet unpublished report
As yet little was known of the causes of the disease.

meanings.def: used to say that while one thing is good, another thing is even better
examples: You can see and, better yet, hear the effects of these changes on their website.
I wanted to make my parents proud by becoming a lawyer or, better yet, a doctor.

meanings.def: not now but probably quite soon
examples: I can't give you the money just yet.

meanings.def: used to comment on something that was almost successful but in fact failed

idioms.def: until now or until a particular time in the past

idioms.idiom: so near and yet so far

related: so near and yet so far

meanings.def: despite what has just been said
examples: It's a small car, yet it's surprisingly spacious.
He has a good job, and yet he never seems to have any money.
